Graphical abstract Fe–N-doped graphene containing 0.3at% of Fe and 1.9 of N with an active specific surface area of 77.5±4m2 g−1 is synthesized in two steps: first N-doped graphene is produced by thermal dissociation of methane in an inductively coupled thermal plasma (ICP) reactor and subsequently the product is converted to Fe–N-doped graphene by a wet chemical method. The catalytic activity of this catalyst toward H2O2 reduction reaction (HPRR) is studied by rotating disk electrode for fuel cell applications. Although the mechanism of HPRR on Fe–N-doped graphene, N-doped graphene and graphene is similar, Fe–N-doped graphene shows the highest catalytic activity toward HPRR. The exchange current density based on the active surface area (j 0 A ) of Fe–N-doped graphene in Na2SO4 solution is (4.4±0.2)×10−8 Acm−2, which is 5 times greater than j 0 A of the N-doped graphene. Direct reduction of H2O2, H2O2 decomposition, O2 reduction, and O2 desorption are predicted as the reactions involved in the HPRR while O2 reduction and O2 desorption are negligible at low and high overpotentials, respectively. Investigation of the effect of the electrolyte and catalyst loading reveals that HPRR on Fe–N-doped graphene suffers from kinetic limitations especially at low catalyst lodgings, fast rotation rates, and strong acidic and basic solutions. Keywords Hydrogen peroxide reduction reaction (HPRR) Fe–N-doped graphene Rotating disk electrode (RDE) Oxygen evolution 1 Introduction Graphene is a two-dimensional form of carbon with atoms arranged in a honeycomb lattice structure. Its unique characteristics such as high specific surface area, chemical stability, and high conductivity make graphene a superior candidate for electrochemical energy systems such as fuel cells [1–3] and lithium ion batteries [4,5]. Recently, there has been intense research effort to replace the conventional noble catalysts such as platinum and gold by graphene-based catalysts in the cathode side of fuel cells. Nitrogen doping increases the catalytic activity of graphene toward both the O2 reduction reaction (ORR) [6–10] and the H2O2 reduction reaction (HPRR) [11,12]. This increase in catalytic activity may be related to the high electronegativity (χ) of nitrogen species which create net positive charges on adjacent carbons facilitating oxygen adsorption [13]. Substitution of some carbon atoms in nitrogen-doped graphene lattice with heteroatoms such as boron (χ =2) with a lower electronegativity than carbon (χ =2.55) creates a unique structure that can be used for ORR [14]. Zheng et al. [14], for instance, showed that the current density produced through ORR on B–N-doped graphene is much higher than the single B- or N-doped graphene. Iron with χ =1.8 also seems to be a suitable chemical element for dual doping of graphene in combination with nitrogen. Fe–N-doped graphene shows high catalytic activity and stability toward ORR in both acidic and alkaline solutions [15,16]. Using a periodic continuum solvation model based on the modified Poisson–Boltzmann equation, Sun et al. have recently shown that both 2e and 4e pathways with OOH as an intermediate product can occur on Fe–N-doped graphene through ORR in acid solution [17]. Although several works have reported the performance of this highly active catalyst toward ORR, the application of Fe–N-doped graphene toward HPRR has not been studied. Hydrogen peroxide is a potential oxidant available in high concentrations in aqueous solutions. As such H2O2 has the potential of replacing O2 to increase the power density of some fuel cells such as membraneless fuel cells and direct borohydride fuel cells with ceramic membrane [18–20]. The most important drawbacks of using H2O2, however, are the slow kinetics of HPRR on non-noble catalysts and the side reaction of the decomposition of H2O2. The O2 produced through the decomposition reaction may be released into the solution leading to the loss of a part of the oxidant and also creating operational problems [12]. We have recently reported the use of graphene nanoflakes (GNFs) and nitrogen-doped graphene nanoflakes with 32% N (N-GNFs32) for the HPRR [12]. Although N-GNFs32 did catalyze HPRR to considerable extent, its catalytic activity was still noticeably lower than polycrystalline gold. Moreover, there was some O2 evolution occurring when this catalyst was used. In this work, three main objectives are pursued: (1) As a part of our effort to find a highly active catalyst for H2O2 reduction with minimum gas evolution, we investigate Fe–N-doped graphene with 0.3at% of Fe and 1.9at% of N (Fe–N-doped graphene) as a catalyst for HPRR. The reaction path and the kinetic parameters such as exchange current density and Tafel slope are determined in 0.1M Na2SO4 solution using a glassy carbon rotating disk electrode (RDE). These results are then compared with N-GNFs32 in order to understand the effect of Fe atoms. (2) The effect of catalyst loading on the kinetic parameters and the intermediate product of HPRR in 0.1M Na2SO4 solution is investigated. Catalyst loading directly affects the thickness of the catalyst film deposited on the glassy carbon RDE. As a result, the characteristics of the catalyst film such as the active surface area available for the reaction(s) may be changed. Catalyst loading may also affect the amount of intermediate products of electrochemical reactions. Bonakdarpour et al. [21], for instance, demonstrated that the amount of the intermediate product of ORR, that is, H2O2, on Fe–N–C catalyst is a function of the catalyst loading. While at high catalyst loadings H2O2 constituted less than 5% of the products, the fraction of H2O2 increased to more than 95% at low catalyst loadings. This result motivates the authors to study the effect of catalyst loading on the intermediate product of HPRR, that is, O2, in order to minimize oxygen evolution from electrode surface. (3) HPRR is also studied on Fe–N-doped graphene in the basic and acidic electrolytes. Electrolyte can affect the mechanism and the kinetics of an electrochemical reaction. The ORR on gold, for instance, has higher catalytic activity in basic electrolyte in comparison with acidic electrolyte [22]. In the current work, the effect of the electrolyte on the mechanism, kinetic parameters such as the exchange current density, and the current density produced through HPRR is studied briefly in 0.1M KOH and 0.5M H2SO4 solutions. 2 Background HPRR may occur through three different paths: (i) direct path (direct reduction of H2O2 by Eq. (1)), (ii) indirect path (H2O2 decomposition by Eq. (2) followed by the reduction of O2 by Eqs. (3) and/or (4)), (iii) a combination of these two paths. Depending on the relative reaction rates of Eqs. (1)–(4) and on the extent of O2 desorption, seven different cases are expected for HPRR [23]. These cases and a short description of the reactions involved in each case are presented in Table 1 . (1) H 2 O 2 + 2 e - + 2 H + → 2 H 2 O (2) 2 H 2 O 2 → O 2 + 2 H 2 O (3) O 2 + 4 e - + 4 H + → 2 H 2 O (4) O 2 + 2 e - + 2 H + → H 2 O 2 According to Table 1, HPRR may occur through complex reaction mechanism. Hence, the Koutecky–Levich equation which is typically used to study simple electrochemical reactions may not be valid to study HPRR. In our previous work [23], the mass transfer equation of the electroactive species (H2O2) inside the solution and the reaction equations on the electrode surface (H2O2 reduction, H2O2 decomposition, O2 reduction, and O2 desorption) were solved simultaneously under the steady state conditions to derive a specific equation for HPRR (Eq. (5)). This new equation presents two apparent reaction rates, k′ and k″ which are functions of the reaction rate constants (k 1–k 5) of different reactions involved in HPRR. Raw data obtained from the RDE are analyzed by using the model Eqs. (5)–(7) shown below and the methodology developed in our previous work [23]. (5) 1 j = 1 j d + 1 j k = - 1 0.62 k ′ nFD 2 / 3 ν - 1 / 6 c ω 1 / 2 - 1 k ″ nFc (6) k ′ = 2 k 1 ( k 3 + k 4 + k 5 ) + k 2 ( 2 k 3 + k 4 ) 2 ( k 1 + k 2 ) ( k 3 + k 4 + k 5 ) - k 2 k 4 (7) k ″ = k 1 ( k 3 + k 4 + k 5 ) + k 2 ( k 3 + 1 2 k 4 ) ( k 3 + k 4 + k 5 ) where j and jd are, respectively, the measured and the diffusion limited current densities based on the geometric surface area of the electrode (Acm−2), jk is the electron transfer current density based on the active surface area of the electrode (Acm−2), k′ (dimensionless) and k″ (cms−1) are two apparent reaction rates, n is the number of electrons involved in Eq. (1), (n =2), D is the diffusion coefficient of H2O2 (1.46×10−6 cm2 s−1) [24], v is the kinematic viscosity of the solution (0.01cm2 s−1), and c is the bulk concentration of H2O2 (1×10−6 molcm−3). The constants k 1 to k 5 are the reaction rate constants of H2O2 reduction (Eq. (1)), H2O2 decomposition (Eq. (2)), O2 reduction by direct pathway (Eq. (3)), O2 reduction by series pathway (Eq. (4)), and O2 desorption, respectively. This equation showed to be more useful than the Koutecky–Levich equation for the analysis of HPRR [23]. Eq. (5) can be used to predict H2O2 decomposition and oxygen evolution from electrode surface. Moreover, this equation provides information about simultaneous reduction of O2 and H2O2. Determination of the heterogeneous reaction rate constant of H2O2 decomposition is another advantage of Eq. (5) in comparison with the Koutecky–Levich equation. According to Eq. (5), a linear relation is expected between the inverse of the current density (j −1) and the inverse square root of the rotation frequency (ω −1/2) when all the reactions involved in the HPRR are first order. The slope and the intercept of these lines can be used to determine k′ and k″, respectively, at different electrode potentials. According to the values of k′ and the relationship between electrode potential (E) and log(k″), the reactions involved in the HPRR are identified (see Table 1) [23]. The value of k′ varies between 0 and 1 depending on the mechanism of HPRR. The upper limit of k′, k′=1, refers to the condition when gas evolution from the electrode surface is negligible [23]. In this condition, HPRR occurs through one of the Cases (a), (b2), or (c1) (see Table 1). Moreover, the O2 produced through the decomposition reaction, if any, is consumed totally through the ORR (Eqs. (3) and (4)). On the other hand, the lower limit of k′, k′ → 0, represents the condition when the current density produced on the electrode surface approaches zero (Case (c2)). In this condition, the direct reduction of H2O2 by Eq. (1) and ORR are negligible. As a result, most O2 molecules on the electrode surface are desorbed into the solution. Hence, values of k′ which are closer to 1 are preferable when the performance of some catalysts toward HPRR are compared for fuel cell application. 3 Experimental 3.1 Catalyst synthesis The catalyst, Fe–N-doped graphene, was synthesized in two steps: first nitrogen-doped graphene nanoflakes (N-GNFs) were produced, and then N-GNFs were converted to the Fe–N-doped graphene using a wet chemical method. The method to produce nitrogen-doped graphene nanoflakes involved the plasma decomposition of methane as the carbon source and nitrogen as the functionalization gas [25–27]. The equipments necessary for the fabrication of graphene nanoflakes were an inductively coupled thermal plasma (ICP) torch (TEKNA PL-35 model; 35kW power) and a radio frequency (RF) generator (Lepel; 60kW power/2–5MHz frequencies). The torch was attached to a custom built conical water-cooled reactor. The conical water-cooled reactor had a length of 50cm and a full angle expansion of 14°. For the N-GNFs synthesized in this work, a 20kW argon plasma was produced at a pressure of 8psia and flow rate of 58standard lmin−1. When the plasma was stable, methane and nitrogen were injected at flow rates of 1 and 0.1standard lmin−1, respectively. The injection time for these two gases was 20min. Once the nitrogen-doped graphene nanoflakes were collected from the ICP reactor, iron was incorporated to the surface using a wet chemical method established by Jaouen et al. [28] for carbon soot materials with ferric acetate (C14H27Fe3O18) as the iron source. The N-GNFs were mixed with an equal amount of 1,10-phenanthroline (C12H18N2) in a water/ethanol mixture and stirred thoroughly in a beaker. Iron acetate was used to make up 1 weight percent of the total solution. After 2h of stirring, the beaker was transferred to a vacuum oven and heated to 95°C for 24h until all of the liquid evaporated. The dried sample was collected off the beaker walls and ball milled in a planetary ball mill for 3h at a speed of 400rotations per minute. The sample then was pyrolyzed in two stages (T =1323 and 1223K) to produce the final product structure [27]. Fig. 1 presents different steps involved in the synthesis of Fe–N-doped graphene. 3.2 Measurements The X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was performed using an ESCALAB MKII at 300W (20mA and 15kV). The radiation source was aluminum, which has an X-ray source energy of 1486.6eV. Raman spectroscopy was performed with an inVia Reflex confocal micro-Raman (Renishaw) with a laser emitting at a wavelength of 514.5nm. Transmission electron microscopy was done on a Philips CM200 equipped with a field emission gun (FEG-TEM). The RDE experiments were conducted in a conventional three electrode cell using a modulated speed rotator (Pine Instruments). Working and counter electrodes were glassy carbon RDE (D =5mm, Pine Instruments) modified with the catalyst and a piece of graphite rod (D =10mm), respectively. The reference electrode was Ag/AgCl electrode (Fisher Scientific) filled with 4M KCl solution. In order to eliminate the effect of light on the decomposition of H2O2, the electrochemical cell was covered with aluminum foil. Dissolved oxygen was purged by bubbling high purity argon into the solution for at least 30min. The oxygen-free solution was maintained throughout the experiments by keeping a flow of argon on the top the solution. An Ecochemie Autolab potentiostat/galvanostat PGSTAT30/FRA2 handled by GPES/FRA v.4.9 software was employed for the RDE measurements. Hydrodynamic voltammograms of polycrystalline gold were recorded by using a gold RDE electrode (D =5mm, Pine Instruments). 3.3 Electrode preparation The appropriate amount of catalyst was dispersed in 1ml of a solution containing 30% ethanol and 70% deionized water. Then, 1μl of 5% Nafion solution (Sigma-Aldrich) and some round ball pellets (plastic) which were already thoroughly washed and sonicated in water and then ethanol were added to the solution. The mixture was sonicated in an ice water bath until a homogenous ink was obtained. The glassy carbon RDE was polished to a mirror finish using alumina suspension (0.05μm). The electrode was sonicated in deionized water and then ethanol for about 2min. The clean electrode was dried in air. Then 3μl of 0.02% Nafion solution (prepared from a 5% Nafion solution diluted with ethanol in our lab) was added to the electrode surface, and it was dried in air. Subsequently 19.6μl of the ink was dropped on the electrode to cover the entire glassy carbon surface. The electrode was dried slowly overnight in the presence of the water vapor until a homogenous, and stable film was obtained. The fresh electrode obtained from the above procedure was directly used for the electrochemical tests. 4 Results and discussion 4.1 Catalyst characterization The XPS results (Table 2 and Fig. S1 of the supporting information) indicate that the catalyst surface is composed of carbon, nitrogen, oxygen, and iron; carbon and oxygen combined represent over 97at%. The signal for iron was faint and not immediately obvious when viewing the whole XPS survey spectrum, but further analysis of the signal showed that iron was present at the surface at a level of 0.3at%. The de-convolution of the iron peak did not provide any substantial information as the signal was close to the detection limit of the XPS instrument. Nitrogen was present on the surface at a level of 1.9at%. A de-convolution of the nitrogen signal assigned 39% of the peak to pyridinic nitrogen, 44% to pyrrolic nitrogen, and the rest to graphitic/quaternary nitrogen. Raman parameters were calculated to evaluate the crystallinity of the catalyst [29]. The purity ratio, a measure of the amount of graphitic content with respect to nongraphitized carbon, was 1.57 indicating a very structured and pure sample [27]. The in-plane dimension of the uniform graphite structures and the average length of the graphene planes were 5.83 and 10.28nm, respectively, both of which are on par with other carbon black materials. The SEM image (Fig. 2 (a)) shows a boulder structure with jagged edges. The size of the boulders mainly varied between 25 and 100μm. The TEM image (Fig. 2(b)) showed that the structure originally consisted of about 12–15 graphene sheets, and this range was maintained throughout all the synthesis steps. Using the voltammetry method [30] (see supporting information for detail), the active specific surface area of Fe–N-doped graphene was determined to be 77.5±4m2 g−1. This value is larger than the active specific surface area of N-doped graphene nanoflakes reported in our previous work (36.7±3m2 g−1) [12] suggesting that iron doping increases disorder in the graphene lattice. 4.2 HPRR on Fe–N-doped graphene Fig. 3 (a) shows the steady state hydrodynamic voltammograms of H2O2 reduction in 0.1M Na2SO4 solution on a Fe–N-doped graphene modified glassy carbon electrode with a catalyst loading of 250μgcm−2. The relationship between j −1 and ω −1/2 at different electrode potentials is shown in Fig. 3(b). The reasonably linear relation observed between these two parameters suggests that the reactions involved in the HPRR are first order. The apparent reaction rate constants, k′ and k″, are determined, respectively, from the slope and the intercept of the lines of Fig. 3(b) at different electrode potentials (Table 3 ). According to the values of k′ reported in Table 3 and the relationship between E and log(k″), three different potential regions are suggested for HPRR on Fe–N-doped graphene: (1) At low overpotentials (E ⩾0.03V), k′ is less than unity, and a linear relation is observed between E vs. log(k″) with a slope of −133mV (Fig. 4(a)). This value is very close to the Tafel slope of 134±3mV determined from the mass transfer corrected Tafel equation (see Tafel slope analysis section). Moreover, Fig. 4 (a) shows a nonlinear relation between E and log(k′). These results suggest that at E ⩾0.03V, HPRR occurs through Case (b1) [23] explained in Table 1. In this case, the reduction and the decomposition of H2O2 occur by comparable reaction rates. Moreover, the desorption of O2 is much faster than the ORR. Hence, the O2 produced through the decomposition reaction is released from the electrode surface before it can be consumed on the electrode. In this case, Eqs. (6) and (7) are simplified to k ′ = k 1 k 1 + k 2 and k ″ = k 1 , respectively. As a result, the following equation can be used to determine the heterogeneous reaction rate constant of H2O2 decomposition (k 2) at different electrode potentials (Table 3). (8) k 2 = k ″ ( 1 - k ′ ) k ′ Table 3 shows that k 2 as determined from Eq. (8) is almost constant at E ⩾0.03V confirming that HPRR occurs through Case (b1) in this potential range. By repeating this experiment a mean value of (2.5±0.4)×10−3 cms−1 was obtained for k 2 on Fe–N-doped graphene in 0.1M Na2SO4 solution. This value is larger than k 2 of N-GNFs32 reported in our previous work (k 2 =(8.66±1.5)×10−4 cms−1) in the same electrolyte and temperature [23]. Hence, increasing the reaction rate constant of H2O2 decomposition is an apparent effect of Fe doping of N-doped graphene. (2) At −0.1⩽ E <0.03V, the k′ is still less than unity (Table 3). Fig. 4(b) shows that a nonlinear relation exists between E and both log(k′) and log(k″). These results suggest that HPRR occur through either Case (b3) or Case (c3) (see Table 1). Case (b3) represents the condition when H2O2 reduction, H2O2 decomposition, O2 reduction, and O2 desorption occur by comparable reaction rates. On the other hand, in Case (c3) the direct reduction of H2O2 is negligible. In this case, the decomposition of H2O2, the reduction and the desorption of O2 occur simultaneously on the electrode surface. According to the above discussion, a part of the O2 produced through the decomposition of H2O2 is released into the solution in both potential ranges. Table 3 shows that k′ is a function of the electrode potential and increases as the electrode potential shifts toward more negative potentials suggesting that the amount of the gas evolution decreases at high overpotentials. (3) At high enough overpotentials (E <−0.1V), k′ approaches unity and HPRR occurs through Case (b2) (see Table 1). In this potential region, ORR is fast enough to consume the oxygen molecules produced through the decomposition of H2O2. Hence, oxygen evolution is minimized. 4.2.1 Tafel slope analysis Tafel equation [31,32] was used to determine the kinetic parameters (cathodic transfer coefficient and exchange current density) of H2O2 reduction on Fe–N-doped graphene: (9) η = 2.3 RT α c n α F ( log j - log j 0 ) where η is the overpotential (V), T is the solution temperature (T =298K), αc is the cathodic transfer coefficient, nα is the total number of electron(s) involved in the rate determining step and all previous step(s), and j 0 is the exchange current density based on the geometric surface area of the electrode (Acm−2). Eq. (9) can be used to determine αc and j 0 , respectively, from the slope and the intercept of the lines between η and log(j). A mean value of 130±6mV was obtained as the Tafel slope of H2O2 reduction on Fe–N-doped graphene by plotting η vs. log(j) at low overpotentials, η <−20mV. This value is sufficiently close to −120mV suggesting that nα =1, that is, the first electron transfer is the rate determining step. Using the Tafel slope and nα =1, αc and j 0 were found to be (0.45±0.02) and (8.55±0.2)×10−6 Acm−2, respectively. The j 0 determined for the Fe–N-doped graphene electrode is noticeably larger than the j 0 of the N-GNFs32 electrode ((7.7±0.3)×10−7 Acm−2) [12] with the same catalyst loading. The exchange current density based on the active surface area of the Fe–N-doped graphene electrode, j 0 A , was then found to be (4.4±0.2)×10−8 Acm−2. This value is five times larger than (8.3±0.3)×10−9 Acm−2 [12] which is the value of j 0 A for H2O2 reduction on N-GNFs32, indicating the higher intrinsic catalytic activity of Fe–N-doped graphene. The results of this section reveal that Fe–N-doped graphene shows higher catalytic activity than N-doped graphene toward HPRR for two main reasons: (1) higher active specific surface area of Fe–N-doped graphene (77.5±4m2 g−1) in comparison with the N-GNFs32 (36.7±3m2 g−1), and (2) higher intrinsic catalytic activity of Fe–N-doped graphene. The stoichiometric number, the number of times that the rate determining step is repeated to finish one cycle of the overall reaction, was determined at very low overpotentials where η →0 by the procedure explained elsewhere [33]. A value of 0.97±0.04 was obtained as the stoichiometric number which is very close to 1. The Tafel slope, stoichiometric number, and cathodic transfer coefficient determined in this work are very close to those values determined for H2O2 reduction on N-GNFs32 and GNFs [12] suggesting that the reduction of H2O2 occur by the same mechanism on these catalysts. The H2O2 molecules are adsorbed on the Fe–N-doped graphene surface through a weak physical bond. Then H2O2 obtains an electron to produce adsorbed OH radical species, (OH)ads, and a hydroxyl ion. Subsequently, the adsorbed OH species obtains one more electron to produce another hydroxyl ion. The mass transfer corrected Tafel equation was used to construct Tafel plots in the mixed control region of voltammograms by plotting E versus log j j d - j for different rotation rates [31]. The value of jd at different rotation rates was determined from j d = - 0.62 k ′ nFD 2 / 3 ν - 1 / 6 c bH ω 1 / 2 while k′ was assumed to be unity (Table 3). Fig. 5 shows the Tafel slope of H2O2 reduction on Fe–N-doped graphene for two rotation rates: 400 and 2500rpm. At E ⩾0.03V, the Tafel slope is constant and independent of the rotation rate suggesting that the simultaneous reduction of H2O2 and O2 is negligible [34,35]. This result is consistent with the result of the previous section suggesting that HPRR occurs through Case (b1) in this potential range. Moreover, the mean value of the Tafel slope was 134±3mV at different rotation rates. At E <0.03V, the Tafel slope is dependent on the rotation rate (Fig. 5) suggesting that the reduction of H2O2 and O2 occurs at comparable reaction rates. This result suggests that HPRR occurs through Case (b3) but not Case (c3) (Table 1) in this potential range. Hydrodynamic voltammograms of HPRR on four different electrodes in 0.1M Na2SO4 solution are shown in Fig. 6 . According to this figure, the current density produced on Fe–N-doped graphene is noticeably higher than GNFs and N-GNFs32 electrodes with the same catalyst loading confirming the high catalytic activity of this electrode. The current density produced on GNFs, N-GNFs32, and Fe–N-doped graphene at E =−0.15V, for instance, are −0.018, −0.1, and −0.52mAcm−2, respectively. 4.2.2 The effect of catalyst loading In this section, HPRR is investigated on Fe–N-doped graphene with three different catalyst loadings of 50, 100, and 250μgcm−2 in 0.1M Na2SO4 solution in order to disclose more information about the mechanism of HPRR on this catalyst. Fig. 7 (a) shows the steady states hydrodynamic voltammograms of Fe–N-doped graphene modified glassy carbon electrode with three different catalyst loadings. According to these results, an increase in the catalyst loading increases the current density produced through HPRR. The current densities observed in this figure are proportional to the catalyst loading at high overpotentials and slow rotation rates. In the previous section, it was observed that the current density produced with this catalyst is also a function of the rotation rate. Hence, HPRR is under the mixed control on Fe–N-doped graphene, that is, both mass transfer and the reaction kinetics are important. Fig. 7(b) shows that the Tafel slope is a function of the catalyst loading. An increase in the catalyst loading from 50 to 100μgcm−2 creates a large difference in the Tafel slope (116mV). Another increase in the catalyst loading from 100 to 250μgcm−2 creates a difference of 24mV in the Tafel slope indicating that the Tafel slope approaching a constant value at high catalyst loadings. These results suggest that the cathodic transfer coefficient increases from 0.22 at the catalyst loading of 50μgcm−2 to 0.49 at the catalyst loading of 250μgcm−2. A transfer coefficient less than 0.5 may be related to the nonuniformity of the catalyst layer [36]. Fig. 8 (a) shows typical j −1 vs. ω −1/2 plots at E ⩽0 for H2O2 reduction on Fe–N-doped graphene electrode with a catalyst loading of 100μgcm−2. According to this figure, j −1 approaches a constant value at ω −1/2 <0.1 (ω >900rpm) indicating that the current density becomes independent of the rotation rate at high rotation rates. This phenomenon can be a sign either for the kinetic [31] or internal mass transport limitations [37]. Fig. 8(b) shows that the plot of electrode potential versus logarithm of the limiting current densities observed in Fig. 8(a) is linear with a slope of −178mV which is reasonably close to the Tafel slope determined for this electrode (−152mV). Hence, these limiting current densities refer to the electron transfer current densities suggesting that HPRR is under the kinetic control in this potential range and high rotation rates. A comparison between Fig. 8(a) and Fig. 3(b) reveals that these liming currents disappeared by increasing the catalyst loading to 250μgcm−2 confirming the presence of the kinetic limitations. An increase in the catalyst loading can increases the active surface area of the electrode and results in enhancing the kinetic currents. This phenomenon, that is , constant current density at high rotation rates, was observed for the electrode with catalyst loading of 50μgcm−2 demonstrating as well the importance of kinetic limitations at low catalyst loadings. Vago et al. [38] suggested that bending j −1 vs. ω −1/2 plots through HPRR is a sign that the decomposition of H2O2 followed by the reduction of O2 occurs on the electrode. This is consistent with the results obtained in the previous section indicating that HPRR occurs through Case (b3) at high overpotentials. Fig. 8(c) shows that j −1 vs. ω −1/2 plots at E >0V are linear indicating the absence of the kinetic limitations. This supports the mechanism suggested in the previous section for HPRR (Case (b1), Table 1) at low overpotentials. The catalyst loading has also an effect on the k′ values which varies between 0 and 1. The values of k′ for two catalyst loadings of 100 and 250μgcm−2 and different electrode potentials are presented in Table 4 . According to this table and the results of the previous sections, at E >0.02V where HPRR occurs through the direct reduction of H2O2 +H2O2 decomposition (Case (b1)), k′ is independent of the catalyst loading. On the other hand, at E <0.02V where HPRR occurs through the direct reduction of H2O2 +H2O2 decomposition+ORR (Case (b3)), k′ is a function of both the electrode potential and catalyst loading. Table 4 shows that the electrode with higher catalyst loading presents higher values of k′ indicating the release of a smaller amount of gas from the surface of this electrode. These results demonstrate the importance of catalyst loading to control gas evolution in the potential ranges where the ORR occurs. 4.2.3 The effect of electrolyte The results presented in the previous section were obtained using an electrolyte having a composition of 0.1M Na2SO4. In this section, HPRR is studied on a Fe–N-doped graphene modified glassy carbon electrode in 0.1M KOH and 0.5M H2SO4 solutions. Fig. 9 (a) shows the hydrodynamic voltammograms in 0.1M KOH solution. The voltammograms at rotation rates faster than 600rpm are almost constant and independent of the rotation rate indicating the slow kinetics of HPRR in the basic solution. At the potentials more positive than −0.3V and at rotation rates slower than 600rpm, the plots of j −1 vs. ω −1/2 are linear. The analysis of k′ and k″ in this potential range suggests that HPRR occurs through either Case (b3) or (c3) explained in Table 1. The k′ was less than unity and increased from 0.36 at E =−0.14V to 0.75 at E =−0.3V suggesting that a part of the O2 produced through the decomposition of H2O2 is desorbed into the electrolyte. Fig. 9(b) shows that j −1 vs. ω −1/2 plots are not linear at E <−0.3V even at slow rotation rates. Hence, Eq. (5) cannot be used to determine the kinetic parameters and the reaction mechanism. The plots tend to curve at a rotation rate as slow as 150rpm (ω −1/2 =0.25(rads−1)−1/2) suggesting a very slow preceding H2O2 decomposition step. Moreover, large Tafel slopes were observed in this potential range at different rotation rates supporting that HPRR occurs thorough chemical electrochemical (CE) reaction mechanism [39]. For instance a Tafel slope of −328mV was observed at 600rpm (data not shown here). These results suggest that HPRR on Fe–N-doped graphene in KOH solution is limited by the slow decomposition reaction at potentials more negative than −0.3V. The reduction of H2O2 on Fe–N-doped graphene with the same catalyst loading was also studied in 0.5M H2SO4 solution. The voltammograms in the studied potential range between 0.5 and −0.2V were independent of the rotation rate indicating that the process is totally under kinetic control in this solution. The exchange current density based on the active surface area of the electrode was determined (3.9±0.3)×10−8 and (3.4±0.4)×10−8 Acm−2 for KOH and H2SO4 solutions, respectively, indicating that the exchange current density is a weak function of the electrolyte. Typically, the exchange current density is more sensitive to the catalyst composition, surface roughness, and temperature [40]. The open circuit potential depended on the solution pH and shifts toward more negative potentials with the increase of the electrolyte pH. The open circuit potential shifted almost −51mV per pH unit which is reasonably close to −59mV/pH, the Nernstian response for a 2e−/2H+ reaction [41]. 4.2.4 HPRR on polycrystalline gold in 0.1M Na2SO4 solution Because gold shows high catalytic activity toward HPRR [34,42], the reduction of H2O2 on polycrystalline gold is studied briefly in this section and the results are compared with those obtained in the previous sections for Fe–N-doped graphene. The analysis of hydrodynamic voltammograms suggests that HPRR on polycrystalline gold occurs through Case (b1) at low overpotentials (see the supporting information). The heterogeneous reaction rate constant of H2O2 decomposition was determined to be (4.7±0.8)×10−3 cms−1. This value is almost two times higher than the value determined for Fe–N-doped graphene, k 2 =(2.5±0.4)×10−3 cms−1, indicating higher catalytic activity of gold toward H2O2 decomposition in 0.1M Na2SO4 solution. A value of (7±1.5)×10−6 Acm−2 was obtained as the exchange current density based on the geometric surface area which is comparable to the value obtained for Fe–N-doped graphene with a catalyst loading of 250μgcm−2 ((8.55±0.2)×10−6 Acm−2). On the other hand, the value of j 0 A was (4.7±1)×10−6 Acm−2 which is almost two orders of magnitude greater than the value determined for Fe–N-doped graphene ((6.1±0.2)×10−8 Acm−2) indicating higher intrinsic catalytic activity of gold in comparison with Fe–N-doped graphene. At high enough overpotentials (E <−0.13V), HPRR occurs through Case (b2). Hence, the O2 desorption from the electrode surface is minimized in this potential range. Table 5 presents a summary of the kinetic parameters (k 2 and j 0 A ) obtained for HPRR on N-GNFs32 [12], Fe–N-doped graphene and polycrystalline gold in 0.1M Na2SO4 solution. The Fe–N-doped graphene sample synthesized in this work contains only 0.3at% of Fe. Synthesis of samples with higher Fe content may be a solution to increase the catalytic activity of Fe–N-doped graphene toward HPRR. 5 Conclusion The results of this work indicate the superior catalytic activity of Fe–N-doped graphene toward H2O2 reduction reaction (HPRR) in comparison with graphene and N-doped graphene. Fe doping creates three important changes on the characteristics and catalytic activity of N-doped graphene: (1) increasing the active specific surface area of the catalyst, (2) increasing the heterogeneous reaction rate constant of H2O2 decomposition, and (3) increasing the exchange current density of H2O2 reduction based on the active surface area of the electrode. The analysis of the RDE voltammograms of HPRR on a Fe–N-doped graphene electrode (catalyst loading of 250μgcm−2) in 0.1M Na2SO4 solution introduces three electrode potential regions: (1) at E ⩾0.03V the direct reduction of H2O2, the decomposition of H2O2, and the desorption of O2 occur by comparable reaction rates, (2) at −0.1⩽ E <0.03V, the direct reduction of H2O2, the decomposition of H2O2, the reduction of O2, and the desorption of O2 are the main reactions on the electrode surface and (3) at potentials more negative than −0.1V, the reduction of H2O2, the decomposition of H2O2, and the reduction of O2 are the main reactions. In this potential region, oxygen evolution from electrode surface is negligible. HPRR on Fe–N-doped graphene suffers from kinetic limitations at low catalyst loadings. These limitations are also observed at fast rotation rates, high electrode potentials, and strong acid and alkaline solutions. Although the exchange current density of a Fe–N-doped graphene modified glassy carbon electrode with a catalyst loading of 250μgcm−2 is comparable with the polycrystalline gold, its exchange current density based on the active surface area is two orders of magnitude smaller than the gold electrode. Increasing the Fe content of Fe–N-doped graphene may be a solution to obtain more active catalysts toward HPRR which can be studied in future works. coredata.dc:description: Fe–N-doped graphene containing 0.3at% of Fe and 1.9 of N with an active specific surface area of 77.5±4m2 g−1 is synthesized in two steps: first N-doped graphene is produced by thermal dissociation of methane in an inductively coupled thermal plasma (ICP) reactor and subsequently the product is converted to Fe–N-doped graphene by a wet chemical method. The catalytic activity of this catalyst toward H2O2 reduction reaction (HPRR) is studied by rotating disk electrode for fuel cell applications. Although the mechanism of HPRR on Fe–N-doped graphene, N-doped graphene and graphene is similar, Fe–N-doped graphene shows the highest catalytic activity toward HPRR. The exchange current density based on the active surface area (j 0 A ) of Fe–N-doped graphene in Na2SO4 solution is (4.4±0.2)×10−8 Acm−2, which is 5 times greater than j 0 A of the N-doped graphene. Direct reduction of H2O2, H2O2 decomposition, O2 reduction, and O2 desorption are predicted as the reactions involved in the HPRR while O2 reduction and O2 desorption are negligible at low and high overpotentials, respectively. Investigation of the effect of the electrolyte and catalyst loading reveals that HPRR on Fe–N-doped graphene suffers from kinetic limitations especially at low catalyst lodgings, fast rotation rates, and strong acidic and basic solutions.
coredata.dc:title: Fe–N-doped graphene as a superior catalyst for H2O2 reduction reaction in neutral solution
